abstract.text: A variety of new physics models predict heavy resonances that decay to multiple hadronic jets.
These models include axigluons, colorons, diquarks, excited quarks, Randall-Sundrum gravitons, string resonances, and Z' models, among others.
Other models make the prediction that high-p T jets will be suppressed, resulting in jet extinction.

Using the data collected in 2012 at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV, the CMS collaboration has made a baseline inclusive jet cross section measurement for comparison with new-physics searches, and then performed searches for jet extinction and resonances that decay to two hadronic jets.
The results of these searches will be presented.
No evidence of new physics has been observed, and these results set new limits on the parameters of these models.
Search for Jet Extinction in the Inclusive
Terascale gravity theories predict that the Planck scale would occur at the TeV scale [11].
In this case, collisions at the LHC could produce microscopic black holes.
Many such theories predict that these black holes would EPJ Web of Conferences 60,

body_text.text: Introduction
A major goal of the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment [1] at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the discovery of new physics (NP) beyond the standard model (SM).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Many NP theoretical models predict jet extinction or production of resonances that decay to paired jets.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: During 2012, the CMS detector recorded 19.6 fb −1 of pp data at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Several CMS analyses have exploited this rich data set to make a measurement of the inclusive jet cross section and to search for these NP signals.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections
The inclusive jet cross section provides an important baseline for comparison with new-physics models.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Additionally, the measurement provides a method of assessment of Quantum Chromodynamic (QCD) calculation frameworks and parton distribution functions (PDFs) used with those frameworks.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: CMS has performed the measurement of the double-differential inclusive jet cross section in terms of p T and rapidity by using 10.7 fb −1 of the 2012 8 TeV pp dataset [2].
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The measurement uses six, staggered triggers to cover a p T range from 74-2500 GeV and a range of parton momentum fraction x from 0.019-0.625.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The data are corrected for detector smearing effects and jet energy resolution.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The dominant systematic uncertainty for data comes from the jet energy scale and ranges from 15-40%.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The theory prediction is calculated at next-to-leadingorder (NLO) by NLOJet++ [3,4] in the fastNLO framework [5].
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Its dominant systematic uncertainty comes a e-mail: cvuosalo@cern.ch  Double-differential inclusive jet cross section (points) in comparison to NLO predictions (red lines) using the NNPDF2.1 PDF set.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Data points are shown for six rapidity ranges.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: from PDF variation and ranges from 10-50%.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The measured cross section matches the theory calculation with the NNPDF2.1 PDF set [6], as shown in Fig. 1.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Data was compared to predictions from five PDF sets: ABM11 [7], CT10 [8], HERAPDF1.5 [9], MSTW2008NLO [10], and NNPDF2.1.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: All match data within the uncertainties except for ABM11 in certain rapidity ranges.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: These results provide strong confirmation for the NLOJet++ calculations and PDFs.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: decay spectacularly in a spray of high-p T jets and particles [12,13], but LHC searches so far have found no evidence for such black hole decay [14][15][16][17][18][19][20][21][22].
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: However, nonperturbative processes could produce black holes that decay to a high multiplicity of low-energy jets [23].
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Such black hole decays might be difficult to distinguish from the low-energy SM background, but their effect on the jetp T spectrum would be dramatic.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: At a certain energy scale, black holes would dominate and thereby suppress the production of high-p T jets, causing jet extinction at the high end of the jet-p T spectrum.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: CMS has performed a search for such jet extinction with 10.7 fb −1 of the 2012 8 TeV pp dataset [24].
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The SM prediction was made at NLO with NLOJet++ in the fastNLO framework and the CT10 PDF set and was scaled to data.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The leading-order extinction spectrum was generated with PYTHIA [25] and assumed the strong-coupling limit of the string model, so jet extinction would occur beyond a scale M. The largest systematic uncertainty comes from the jet energy scale and is about 10%.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The data was found to match the SM prediction within the uncertainties, as seen in Figs. 2 and 3.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: A 95% confidence level (CL) limit at 3.3 TeV on scale M was set with the CL S calculator, as shown in Fig. 4.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: For the NLOJet++ calculator, there are a number of PDF sets that can be employed, in addition to the CT10 PDF used for the SM estimate.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: The variation between PDF sets is bracketed by the CT10 and MSWT2008 sets.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Thus, as a cross check, the MSWT2008 set was tried for the SM estimate, and it increased the observed limit by only 10%, thereby confirming the CT10 limit of 3.3 TeV as a conservative value.
body_text.section: Measurement of Differential Inclusive Jet Cross Sections

body_text.text: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum
Many new physics models predict heavy resonances that couple to quarks and gluons and decay to dijets.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Some   of these models include axigluons (A) [26,27], coloroctet colorons (C) [28], excited quarks [29,30], Randall-Sundrum gravitons [31], scalar diquarks [32], string resonances [33,34], technicolor s8 resonances [35], and new gauge bosons (W' and Z') [36].
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: CMS has performed searches for such resonances, first with 4.0 fb −1 [37], and then with the full 19.6 fb −1 2012 8 TeV pp dataset [38].
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: This search employs the wide-jet technique [39][40][41], which adds close sub-leading jets to the two leading jets in each selected event.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Figure 5 shows a CMS event display of the dijet event with the highest invariant mass in this dijet search.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Figure 6.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Dijet mass spectrum from wide jets (points) compared to a smooth fit (solid) and to predictions including detector simulation of QCD and signal resonances.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The QCD prediction has been normalized to the data.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The error bars are statistical only.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The bin-by-bin fit residuals, (data-fit)/σ data , are shown at the bottom.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The background prediction comes from a fourparameter fit to the data.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The largest systematic uncertainty is the jet energy resolution uncertainty, which is 10%.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: The data matches the background estimate with no excess or bumps observed on the smooth background, as shown in Fig. 6.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Mass limits are set on the eight signal models, as shown in Fig. 7, with the strongest limit being 5.1 TeV on the string resonance mass.
body_text.section: Search for Narrow Resonances using the Dijet Mass Spectrum

body_text.text: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

As a variation on the dijet search in Sec. 4, a b-jet tagging requirement can be placed on the jets in order to reduce SM backgrounds and to make the search sensi- tive to models that specifically produce b jets: excited b quarks [29,30], RS gravitons [31], and a sequential SM Z' [36].
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: CMS has performed such a search with the full 19.6 fb −1 2012 8 TeV pp dataset [42].
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: Like the previous analysis, this one uses the wide-jet technique and a background estimate from a four-parameter fit to the data.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: Because the b-tagging rate drops significantly for highmass signal resonances, as shown in Fig. 8, the analysis is performed in three channels: 0 b tags, 1 b tag, and 2 b tags.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: The largest systematic uncertainty comes from the jet energy resolution and is about 10%.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: The background estimates compared to the data are shown in Fig. 9.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: The data match the background estimates within the uncertainties, and no excess is observed.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: The best mass limits to date are set on the three signal models, as shown in Fig. 10, with the strongest limit being 1.7 TeV on the Z' mass.
body_text.section: Search for Heavy Resonances Decaying into bb and bg Final States

body_text.text: Conclusion
The CMS Collaboration has measured the inclusive jet cross section and performed several searches for new physics using jets with the 2012 8 TeV pp collision dataset.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The jet cross section measurement has confirmed the NLOJet++ calculations and PDF sets.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In the searches, no significant deviations from the SM were observed.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: New limits have been set on many models, most being the best to date on these models.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: These limits range up to 3.3 TeV on the jet extinction scale, up to 5.1 TeV on dijet string resonances, and up to 1.7 TeV on a Z'.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: CMS is continuing its searches for new physics, and more results will be coming out soon.
body_text.section: Conclusion
